Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Documenting the endangered Koman languages and their linguistic relationships

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Just like biologists have methods to investigate the relationships between species, linguists have methods that allow them to determine the relationships between languages. Linguists do this by comparing a set of languages along various dimensions, such as words or language structures that may have a common origin. Documentation of individual languages plays a key role in how scholars reconstruct the family relationships between languages, but with little or no documentation, it is highly challenging to make conclusive determinations of the linguistic relationships. This project will investigate a small set of five endangered languages which are related to each other, according to the existing small sets of data. These languages are poorly documented due to being spoken only in a remote, conflict-ridden area, inaccessible except by footpaths. This project will also research whether these languages are related to others in the neighboring geographic region by documenting the individual languages in this group, and by making comparisons between specific words and other linguistic features of each of the languages. The dissertation will increase the linguistic understanding of the five targeted languages and their relationships with each other and with other languages in the region. This dissertation will also add deeper insight to the less frequent type of patterns ("typology") in the sound systems and in grammar of these languages by collecting and analyzing new documentation. The documentation will serve not only linguists and educators but also anthropologists and historians interested in the inhabitants of a virtually forgotten area.



In this dissertation project, doctoral student Manuel Otero will document the endangered languages, including a comparative vocabulary of the Koman peoples. The Koman languages constitute a small group of five languages spoken in the Ethiopia, Sudan and South Sudan borderlands. Aside from Uduk, the Koman languages are only spoken in Africa, so fieldwork will be carried out primarily in Ethiopia for the Komo, Gwama, Opuo and Dana languages. Little is known about the Koman languages and peoples, as the terrain these groups have inhabited for centuries is rugged and primarily communicable by footpaths. Most Koman people continue traditional practices, including hunting and gathering alongside subsistence farming. Impacted by more than a century of strife and conflict, these populations continue to dwindle and some of their languages are on the verge of extinction, in urgent need of documentation. The primary research questions concern developing an understanding of their sound systems and grammar, their interrelationships, and how Koman relates to larger African language families, which is still under debate. Typologically rare grammatical features in Koman include temporal distinctions made by suffixes that primarily indicate direction of movement and track the location of participants. Such systems are important to the study of human language and cognition, as they show how grammatical material can evolve. In Koman languages, the grammar of "tense" is developing out of the human desire to communicate the whereabouts of other animate beings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
While the number of languages spoken in the world continues to dwindle, the majority of languages are spoken by smaller and smaller populations. Many of these communities are culturally assimilating to more dominant communities, and with this assimilation comes linguistic assimilation, language loss, and loss of traditional cultural knowledge. In light of these issues, two of the major scientific concerns in the field of Linguistics are to gain an understanding of: 1. the range of possible variation exhibited in the structures of languages (e.g. in their sound systems and grammar) and 2. how languages evolve historically as communities are isolated from, or interact with, other communities. The latter allows us to group languages into language families, along with the reconstruction of original parent languages from which daughter languages have descended. This project addressed these questions by examining the Koman languages, a small and relatively unstudied family of languages spoken by minority communities that inhabit the rugged and remote borderlands of Ethiopia, Sudan and South Sudan. The Co-PI carried out fieldwork and collected data from speakers of all of the living Koman languages in Ethiopia as well as from Sudanese refugee populations in Utah.

 

The Koman family is significant to African linguistics and African history for several reasons. First, many of the languages are poorly documented and in peril of extinction. Second, Koman’s genetic affiliation, in a linguistic sense, to larger African language families is still under debate. In order to determine the linguistic relationships between languages, linguists employ scientific methods, much like in biology, and compare the words and grammar in order to determine if the languages in question indeed form a genetic unit. From here, the internal structure of a language family can be empirically determined (e.g. the “sister” and “daughter” languages) and the proto-language (i.e. the “parent” language) can be reconstructed.

 

To these ends, this project provided extensive documentation and descriptions of the phonological (i.e. the sound system) and the core grammatical elements of the living Koman languages, including many previously unstudied subvarieties of those languages. It provided an extensive comparative wordlist accompanied by detailed transcription and high-quality audio recordings. This project also produced the first substantive reconstruction of the Proto-Koman language based on firsthand data collected in the field. It highlighted important features of the Proto-Koman sound system and grammar, and detailed the historical changes in each of the branches of the Koman genetic tree, down to the modern living languages. It also discovered a new Koman language, Dana, which was previously unrecognized. The Proto-Koman reconstruction documentation of changes ultimately hopes to serve not only scientific large-scale linguistic classifications of African languages in eastern Africa, but also the study of African prehistory and interactions among cultures and ethnicities. The documentary data also serve humanitarian ends such as the production of dictionary, literacy, and other educational materials, and literacy workshops for the communities.
